**G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as this action seeks modification of an existing Probate and Family Court custody judgment concerning minor children domiciled in Bristol County.

**G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**, and **G.L. c. 215, § 6**, as this action seeks modification of an existing Probate and Family Court custody judgment concerning minor children domiciled in Bristol County.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Modification of custody requires a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and a showing that modification is in the children’s **best interests**.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/custodial-relocation decision made in the original divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification case. The court interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and applies a “real advantage”/best-interests analysis to whether the custodial parent may remove the children from Massachusetts, but it does not state that a modification of custody requires a material and substantial change in circumstances. The ‘material and substantial change’ standard is not discussed or applied in this case.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.proposition: Modification of custody requires a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and a showing that modification is in the children’s **best interests**.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody context, and frames the standard as whether removal is in the children’s best interests. Although the opinion cites the ALI Principles, which refer to relocation as a potential “substantial change in circumstances,” the Massachusetts court does not adopt or articulate a general rule that any modification of custody requires a material and substantial change plus best interests. The holding is about the best‑interests standard for removal, not a two‑part ‘material and substantial change’ test for custody modification generally.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Court has continuing jurisdiction to alter custody orders when necessary to promote the children’s welfare under **G.L. c. 208, § 28** and **G.L. c. 209C, § 20**; see also *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt deals with standards for custody determinations in the context of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings, but it does not address the court’s continuing jurisdiction to modify custody orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28, or G.L. c. 209C, § 20. Neither statute is cited, and there is no discussion of the probate court’s ongoing power to alter prior custody orders as circumstances change. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific continuing-jurisdiction proposition claimed.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: A breakdown in parental communication sufficient to impair joint decision-making may justify modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses when joint custody is appropriate and rejects it here because the parents are severely antagonistic and fundamentally disagree on major child-rearing issues. The court emphasizes that joint custody requires the ability to work together on major decisions and that, in this high-conflict situation, joint custody would be "an invitation to continued warfare and conflict" contrary to the children’s best interests. This directly supports the idea that a breakdown in parental communication and cooperation justifies modifying away from joint decision‑making arrangements.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: However, we agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually “to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.” ... Although complete agreement between parents to implement joint custody may not be necessary, in order to be effective “joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions....” ... The judge concluded that “joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2.proposition: The best interests standard remains paramount, requiring consideration of each parent’s ability to provide for the children’s emotional and physical needs.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reiterates that in custody matters the best interests of the child are the paramount concern, and it applies that standard by comparing each parent’s capacity to meet the child’s physical, medical, educational, and daily needs. The court upholds the trial judge’s order as a proper exercise of discretion under this best-interests framework and emphasizes that all relevant factors bearing on the child’s welfare must be weighed, including each parent’s ability to provide for the child’s emotional and physical welfare.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’)… However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … [T]he mother is more ‘attuned’ to Kali’s medical, educational, and daily needs and is better able to provide for Kali’s welfare and physical needs during the week.”

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409.proposition: The best interests standard remains paramount, requiring consideration of each parent’s ability to provide for the children’s emotional and physical needs.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly reaffirms that the governing and controlling principle in custody determinations is the welfare (best interests) of the child, which includes reference to present and probable future well-being. While it does not expressly enumerate “each parent’s ability to provide for the children’s emotional and physical needs,” the material facts and the judge’s reasoning focus on which household actually met the child’s physical and emotional needs, so the case implicitly applies the best-interests standard in that manner. Thus it generally supports, though not in those exact words, the claimed proposition.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406, 409.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’… ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child… the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 496 (20.proposition: Persistent disparagement of a co-parent in the children’s presence can constitute a change warranting modification because it undermines children’s emotional health and stability.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 496 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats a parent’s disparaging and alienating conduct toward the co-parent, in the child’s presence, as behavior that harms the child’s emotional well-being and is a central factor in the best-interests analysis supporting a change in custody. The court affirms the trial judge’s finding that such alienating and disparaging behavior—e.g., calling the other parent a derogatory name in front of the child and undermining the parent-child relationship—caused or risked long-term harm to the child, thereby justifying a change in custodial arrangements.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 496 (20.relevant_excerpt: The judge listed the ways Rose’s behavior exacerbated the harm to Jill, including… engaging in behaviors demonstrating an attempt to alienate Jill from Hunter, such as… telling Jill that Hunter was not her parent but a “friend,” and referring to Hunter as “the person,” “someone,” or “Amy”; calling Hunter a “dickwad” in front of Jill… The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded… it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 546\.proposition: Joint legal custody presumes the ability of the parents to communicate and cooperate effectively; where cooperation breaks down, modification to sole legal custody may be proper.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 546\.support_reasoning: This concurrence concerns relocation and the statutory rights of an unmarried mother with sole legal custody before paternity is adjudicated. The proposition about joint legal custody and modification therefore is not addressed or supported by this opinion.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 546\.relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. ... As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’ ... The paternity statute further provides that ‘the mother shall continue to have custody after an adjudication of paternity or voluntary acknowledgment of parentage’ (emphasis added) unless and until a court orders otherwise. G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (b)."

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Joint legal custody presumes the ability of the parents to communicate and cooperate effectively; where cooperation breaks down, modification to sole legal custody may be proper.

*Mazzone v. Mazzone*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The integrity of parenting time must be preserved to maintain children’s relationships with each parent, and unilateral scheduling decisions contrary to a court order may warrant adjustment.

The proposition attributed to Mazzone v. Mazzone is therefore unrelated to the issues actually decided in this case.
*Mazzone v. Mazzone*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: We discern no evidence in the record before us to support the determination that the partnerships’ investment activities, done solely on their own behalf, rose to the level of a trade or business. The emphasis placed by the board and the commissioner upon the language of the partnership agreements referring to the “business” of the partnerships and requiring Shaevel to “operate the business of the partnership” is off the mark since such language is far from dispositive as to whether the partnerships are properly treated as a business for tax purposes.

*Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 517.proposition: Massachusetts law requires that any custody modification promote stability, predictability, and consistency in the children’s environment.
*Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 517.support_reasoning: The case discusses termination of parental rights and permanency planning, not standards for modification of custody orders. While the court emphasizes the importance of permanence and stability in children’s lives, it does not state any general doctrinal rule that Massachusetts law requires every custody modification to promote stability, predictability, and consistency. The proposition overstates and reframes the opinion’s reasoning in a different procedural context (care and protection/termination vs. custody modification).
*Adoption of Nancy*, 443 Mass. 512, 517.relevant_excerpt: "Here we have a case where the children are finally in stable situations. ... After waiting five years in the hope that their father would treat his alcohol addiction, it is not now in their best interests to ask the girls to wait an unknown additional period... Stability in the lives of children is important, particularly in a case that has continued for a long period of time... We agree with the judge that these children deserve permanence and stability, which will be eased by termination of their father’s rights."
